datafield.subfield: String networks in Z_N Lotka-Volterra competition models

String networks in Z_N Lotka-Volterra competition models
00000 Possible predator-prey interactions in the cases with $4$ and $5$ species.

00001 This figure schematically describes the organization of the species around the defect cores. The black dots represent a topological defect/antidefect pair of 4 (left panel) and 5 (right panel) species.
00002 (color online) Snapshot of the evolution of the $5$ species model on a $512^2$ lattice after $5000$ generations. The darker regions in the right panel represent the defect cores.

00006 Snapshots obtained after $730$, $850$, $920$ and $1000$ generations of a $128^3$ stochastic network simulation with $N=5$. The five species are left uncolored while the blue regions represent regions with a significantly larger density of empty spaces. The vertical arrows signal an intercommutation process while the horizontal ones indicate the collapse of a string loop.

00007 Snapshots obtained after $730$, $850$, $920$ and $1000$ generations of a $128^3$ stochastic network simulation with $N=5$. The five species are left uncolored while the blue regions represent regions with a significantly larger density of empty spaces. The vertical arrows signal an intercommutation process while the horizontal ones indicate the collapse of a string loop.

The five species are left uncolored while the blue regions represent regions with a significantly larger density of empty spaces. The vertical arrows signal an intercommutation process while the horizontal ones indicate the collapse of a string loop.

00014 Snapshots obtained after $2000$, $4000$ and $6000$ generations (from left to right, respectively) of $1024^2$ mean field (upper panels) and stochastic (lower panels) string network simulations of the 5 species model, starting with similar initial conditions.
00015 Circular string loop in a model with 5 species.
00016 The time evolution of the area of circular strings for models $N=4$ and $N=5$ with the dashed lines representing the best fits.
00017 The average scaling exponent $\lambda$ computed from ensebles of ten $1024^2$ and $256^3$ network simulations of models with $N=4$ and $N=5$. The best fits are represented by the dashed lines.

00002 Snapshot of the evolution of the $4$ (upper panels) and $5$ (bottom panels) species model on a $512^2$ lattice after $5000$ generations. The core regions in the right panels represent the defect cores inside the small region of the left panel indicated by a box.

00003 Snapshot of the evolution of the $4$ (upper panels) and $5$ (bottom panels) species model on a $512^2$ lattice after $5000$ generations. The core regions in the right panels represent the defect cores inside the small region of the left panel indicated by a box.

00004 Snapshot of the evolution of the $4$ (upper panels) and $5$ (bottom panels) species model on a $512^2$ lattice after $5000$ generations. The core regions in the right panels represent the defect cores inside the small region of the left panel indicated by a box.

00005 Snapshot of the evolution of the $4$ (upper panels) and $5$ (bottom panels) species model on a $512^2$ lattice after $5000$ generations. The core regions in the right panels represent the defect cores inside the small region of the left panel indicated by a box.

In this letter we give specific examples of Z_N Lotka-Volterra competition models leading to the formation of string networks. We show that, in order to promote coexistence, the species may arrange themselves around regions with a high number density of empty sites generated by predator-prey interactions between competing species. These configurations extend into the third dimension giving rise to string networks. We investigate the corresponding dynamics using both stochastic and mean field theory simulations, showing that the coarsening of these string networks follows a scaling law which is analogous to that found in other physical systems in condensed matter and cosmology.
